qas.question: Ashkenazi Jews share more common paternal lineages with what group?
Jewish traditions place most Jewish paternal origins in which region?
Which lineages are generally more heterogeneous?
What tends to imply a large number of founders in an old population?
What do male line ancestors appear to be outside of Jewish populations?

plausible_answers.text: Scholars such as Harry Ostrer and Raphael Falk

qas.question: Who believes many Jewish males did not find new mates from European communities?
What percent of Ashkenazi Jews originate from four male founders?

plausible_answers.text: the large portion of non-local maternal origin among Ashkenazi Jews

qas.question: What did studies carried out by Feder not confirm?

context: Y <b3_0>DNA studies<b3_0/> tend to imply a small number of founders in an old population whose members parted and followed different migration paths. In most Jewish populations, these male line ancestors appear to have been <b4_0>mainly Middle Eastern<b4_0/>. For example, Ashkenazi Jews share more common paternal lineages with other <a0_0>Jewish and Middle Eastern groups<a0_0/> than with non-Jewish populations in areas where Jews lived in Eastern Europe, Germany and the French Rhine Valley. This is consistent with Jewish traditions in placing most Jewish paternal origins in the region of the <a1_0>Middle East<a1_0/>. Conversely, the <a2_0>maternal lineages<a2_0/> of Jewish populations, studied by looking at mitochondrial DNA, are generally more heterogeneous. <b5_0>Scholars such as Harry Ostrer and Raphael Falk<b5_0/> believe this indicates that many Jewish males found new mates from European and other communities in the places where they migrated in the diaspora after fleeing ancient Israel. In contrast, Behar has found evidence that about <b6_0>40%<b6_0/> of Ashkenazi Jews originate maternally from just four female founders, who were of Middle Eastern origin. The populations of Sephardi and Mizrahi Jewish communities "showed no evidence for a narrow founder effect." Subsequent studies carried out by Feder et al. confirmed <b7_0>the large portion of non-local maternal origin among Ashkenazi Jews<b7_0/>. Reflecting on their findings related to the maternal origin of Ashkenazi Jews, the authors conclude "Clearly, the differences between Jews and non-Jews are far larger than those observed among the Jewish communities. Hence, differences between the Jewish communities can be overlooked when non-Jews are included in the comparisons."
